title: Business and Company Law
requirements: For students in PgD Professional Accountancy; or Master of Accountancy
description: This course introduces students to the institutions, doctrine and methodology of the law in the business and corporation contents. After a discussion of the legal system of Hong Kong SAR, the first part of the course examines selected subjects in contract, tort of negligence, employment, and sales of goods. The second part of the course will focus on company law, such as formation of companies, the effects of incorporations, the division of powers and obligations among various organs of the company, its relationship with outsiders, financing and dividend issues, and options available to companies in financial difficulties.

locations: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall2

outcome: Students can know the important rules of business law and company law at the end of the course. These rules concern how the courts deal with business-related disputes and issues relating to the running of companies in the real life. As many of the rules are designed to protect consumers and shareholders, students can in particular know more about consumers’ rights and shareholders’ rights. In addition, they can also learn more analytical skills and writing skills which can help them to apply the rules to do their assessments.

title: Taxation and Tax Planning
requirements: For students in PgD Professional Accountancy; or Master of Accountancy
description: This course covers the basic elements and statutes of Hong Kong taxation system, including salaries tax, property tax, profits tax, personal assessment, depreciation allowances, and tax administration. After this basic knowledge, the course will introduce advanced concepts of tax planning, problem solving with practical examples and the inter-relationships between different types of taxes. Local tax cases will be discussed extensively.

instructors: Dr KAN FU Mee Yuk Shirley

outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: 1. understand the basic rules of Hong Kong Taxation, 2. compute the tax payable under different taxes, and 3. develop basic tax planning techniques.

title: Accounting
description: The primary objective of the course is to provide students with a solid conceptual and practical understanding of financial accounting. Emphasis is placed on understanding the content and principles underlying financial statements. From this a sound foundation is built on which students can make more informed business judgments and decisions.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: a) Distinguish among financial vs managerial vs tax accounting b) Identify the economic events that are to be included in the financial reports c) Apply the classification criteria for revenues, expenses, assets, liabilities, and equity accounting d) Distinguish between cash and accrual accounting e) Prepare and analyze financial statements f) Explain cost relations and types and apply cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis g) Apply relevant cost analysis  h) Describe the roles of budgeting, standard costing, and variance analysis i) Acknowledge and demonstrate limitations of purely accounting-based decision making

title: Accounting for Business Decisions
description: The primary objective of the course is to provide students with a solid conceptual and practical understanding of financial and managerial accounting. Emphasis is placed on understanding the concepts and principles underlying financial statements and cost, volume and profit analysis. From this a sound foundation is built on which students can make more informed business judgments and decisions.
outcome: By completing this course, students will be able to: 1. Distinguish clearly among financial vs managerial vs tax accounting 2. Identify the economic events that are to be included in the financial reports 3. Demonstrate and apply the classification criteria for revenues, expenses, assets, liabilities, and equity accounting 4. Highlight the important distinction between cash and accrual accounting 5. Prepare and analyze financial statements 6. Explain cost relations and types and apply cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis 7. Describe the roles of budgeting, standard costing, and variance analysis 8. Acknowledge and demonstrate limitations of purely accounting-based decision making
syllabus: - Introduction to financial accounting - Bookkeeping and transaction analysis - The balance sheet, income statement and cash flow - Corporate governance - Financial analysis - Introduction to managerial accounting - Cost-volume-profit relationships - Cost analysis for planning and control - Cost analysis for decision making
required_readings: Accounting: What the Numbers Mean, latest edition, by Marshall, McManus, and Viele, McGraw Hills, ISBN: 987-0-07-122102-3
recommended_readings: Optional internet resources as reference readings: http://www.accountingcoach.com/

title: Corporate and Financial Law
description: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to obtain essential legal knowledge and skills in relation to companies and financial markets. Its primary objective is to develop a contextual and practical understanding of key issues in the areas of corporate and financial law. Principal topics include financial regulatory framework, incorporation, corporate governance issues, shareholder remedies, securities offering and listing, market misconduct, takeover of listed companies and internet finance.
outcome: Students who have successfully completed this course will be able to: • demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the corporate and financial law relevant to the topics covered in the subject; • make use of rules and regulations issued by the regulatory bodies when assessing the state of the law;  • identify and analyze the legal issues that typically arise in the subject area.

title: Business Law
description: This course is designed to develop knowledge and skills in the understanding of the general legal framework and legal issues that arise from day-to-day business activities. Through the study of cases and legislation, it aims to cultivate the analytical skills of students within a legal context. Topics to be covered may include the Hong Kong legal system, contract law, the law of torts, employment law, the formation and constitution of business organizations, capital and the financing of companies, management, administration and the regulation of companies, the winding up of companies, governance and ethical issues relating to business.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are able to: a) Understand the legal principles, general legal framework and legal issues for business b) Understand the process of merger and acquisition, rights of minority’s shareholders, and the new competition law c) Develop analytical skills for business decision within a legal context

title: Fundamental Accounting – Financial Statement Analysis
description: The objective of this course is to provide an in-depth analysis of the requirement and practice of financial reporting and financial disclosure in mainland China and listed Chinese companies, including A-share, B-share, and H-share firms. The course consists of four parts: 1) the legal and regulatory framework; 2) the reporting and disclosure process; 3) issues in analysing IPO prospectus; and 4) issues in analysing annual/interim reports. The course will be a mix of lectures, class discussion, and cases.
outcome: Students will: - be able to read financial statements - understand the principles of drafting financial statement - be able to understand how external environment and internal factors influence the value relevance of accounting information of enterprises - be able to apply economic intuition and dynamic method to analyse the effect of enterprise management, investment and financing strategies on accounting information

title: Contemporary Management Accounting
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy;Prerequisite: ACCT5111
description: This course examines the use of contemporary accounting systems for cost measurement, control, performance evaluation, and as a source of sustainable competitive advantage. The course begins with discussion of cost concepts and traditional accounting control and costing systems and then proceeds to examination of contemporary accounting systems including activity-based systems for product pricing, cost control and customer profitability management, and EVA and Balanced Scorecard systems for strategic control and performance evaluation. Practical exposure to the use of these systems in decision-making and the issues involved in their design and implementation are provided through the use of case analysis, current research and student projects. Prerequisite: ACCT5111
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to use accounting information in decision analysis and control, including cost analysis and control, profit planning, budgeting, variance analysis, responsibility accounting, and incentive system design and implementation.

title: Company Law and Security Law of China
description: This course provides an introduction to the legal system of China’s capital market. Topics covered include: the corporate governance of companies, the process of companies going public, the information disclosure requirement of listed companies, and security trading regulations in China.
outcome: Students will: - be familiar with existing Chinese rules and practices - be able to identify and compare different conceptions of and approaches to law to bring home systemic problems China has encountered in its modernization efforts - be familiar with the economic, political and historical backgrounds of company law as well as main provisions of PRC company legislation - be able to analyse cases concerning various company law issues that have been litigated - have thorough understanding of problems of securities markets and investor protection as well as theories dealing with those problems - be familiar with legal issues related to the issuance and transactions of securities as well as liabilities of different actors

title: Accounting Field Study
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy
description: The course is designed to expose students to a wide spectrum of global accounting related issues in a non-local business environment. Students will take a week-long residential programme in various countries or regions. Course learning activities include lectures at universities, case projects, seminars and discussions with local accounting professionals and/or government officials, and site visits to enterprises.
outcome: After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: 1. understand accounting practice in different countries and regions 2. understand business models of different enterprises and the supporting role of accounting  3. communicate effectively and efficiently in a professional way
syllabus: 1: Classroom lectures Students will take classroom lectures at universities in the visiting countries and regions. The purpose of classroom lectures is to help students understand local accounting practice.  2: Group case project Students will be required to study business models of the enterprises they will visit and present their findings to the class. The purpose of the group case project is to help students better understand the enterprises and relevant industries, and learn more about the supporting role of accounting from the visits.  3: Visits to enterprises Visits to enterprises will be arranged. Through these visits, students have chances to know about operating process and accounting practice of real-world enterprises. They also have chances to talk to management of those enterprises to understand how accounting helps enterprises implement their business models.

title: Field Study for Accounting Managers
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: The course is designed to expose students to a wide spectrum of global accounting related issues in a non-local business environment. Students will take at least a week-long residential programme in various countries or regions. Course learning activities include lectures and/or seminars at universities, discussions with local accounting professionals and/or government officials, and site visits to enterprises.

title: Financial Accounting Theory
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy
description: This course establishes a framework for evaluating accounting choices and categorizing the strength of authority for particular accounting treatments. This is accomplished by exposing the students to empirical accounting research and by creating an awareness of the endogenous factors affecting accounting decisions. Major themes are the integration of cash flow and accrual based measures of income from a theoretical perspective and the synthesis of accounting choice questions based on the asset valuation versus income measurement dichotomy. The end result will be a deeper understanding of both the structure and the process of accounting policy-making.

title: Business Valuation and Analysis
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: This course introduces a framework for business valuation analysis using corporate disclosure and financial statement data. The framework identifies four key components of valuation: business strategy analysis, accounting analysis, financial analysis, and prospective analysis. Employing a case methodology, applications of this framework in a variety of decision-making contexts including securities analysis, credit analysis, and merger and acquisition decisions are examined.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to: a) Develop a comprehensive framework for business analysis and valuation by identifying and utilizing value relevant information provided in the financial statements b) Analyze accounting policies, evaluate earnings quality and make necessary adjustments to financial statements c) Apply appropriate financial tools to perform critical analysis on firm’s profitability, liquidity, solvency and asset utilization d) Formulate sound financial decisions under context-specific settings by incorporating the strategic, accounting and financing activities of a business entity into the performance/valuation analysis e) Show the competency in writing a thorough, credible and professional financial statement analysis report

title: Comparative Financial Reporting
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: This course examines the evolution of accounting under different political and economic systems and explores current theory and research on the impact of local institutional features on financial reporting and disclosure practices. In so doing, it provides participants with a conceptual framework for analyzing the economic causes and consequences of differences in reporting and disclosure practices and their impact on international commerce, finance, and investment. The course includes discussion of recent and proposed changes in reporting standards with a focus on the local and Mainland reporting environment.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to: a) Understand the major differences among IFRS, US GAAP and China Accounting Standards, and the progress in their convergences.  b) Understand the economic consequences of accounting policies and choices from the perspectives of investors, managers, and government regulators.  c) Improve the ability of making good judgment to complex business transactions.

title: Comprehensive Budget Management
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: The course introduces to students a systematic and scientific budget management system. Through case studies, students can understand how to prepare a reasonable budget, how to promote communication between enterprise and departments, how to clear and quantify the company's business objectives, how to develop and continuously adjust the business plan and use the budget to regulate the management of the company, and finally how the financial budget becomes a comprehensive budget that can guarantee the success of the company.
outcome: After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: (1) understand the importance of a comprehensive budget for a company to achieve its strategic goals (2) understand the key points of an efficient and comprehensive budget management system (3) understand the building ideas for a company's budget management system (4) understand the processes, tools and methods of budgeting (5) master an effective way to monitor and evaluate business operations through budget management
syllabus: Topics include: - budget management - budget, strategy and goals - process and method of budget preparation - effective implementation and control of the overall budget - comprehensive budget tracking and analysis - comprehensive budget assessment - promotion strategy and function positioning of budget management - common analysis of the difficulty of budget management
required_readings: To be provided by the course teacher.

title: Management Control Systems
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: Designed properly, management control systems serve to influence and structure employee behavior in ways that increase the likelihood that organizational objectives are achieved or exceeded. This course provides an advanced-level examination of the alternative control mechanisms available to organizations, theories underlying their use, and their intended and often unintended effects on behavior. Particular attention is directed to the critical decisions underlying the design of effective accounting based control systems including choice of responsibility structure, performance measures, performance standards, and incentive systems, and to emerging issues in corporate governance.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: a) Be equipped with basic concepts of management control systems b) Understand the design and implementation of various control structures and tools using management accounting

title: Advances in Strategic Management Accounting
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: This is an advanced course in management accounting examining the role of management accounting systems in strategy formation and implementation and as a potential source of sustainable competitive advantage. The course blends current research with practical exposure to the issues involved in the design and implementation of these systems. Topics include cost of capacity, activity-based management systems for operational and strategic control and contemporary approaches to performance coordination and evaluation in a decentralized environment.

title: Assurance Services and Information Technology
requirements: For student in Master of Accountancy;Prerequisite: ACCT5130
description: This course examines Hong Kong legal environment and discusses how it will affect audit risk, audit planning, internal controls, analytical procedures, and substantive tests. Building on this foundation, this course then focuses on information technology and examines its impacts on financial reporting systems. Specifically, we emphasize on how auditors can leverage information technology and use Computer-Assisted Audit Tools and Techniques (CAAT) to attest clients’ financial statements.

title: Accounting Information Systems and Internal Control
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or Master of Accountancy
description: This course consists of two related areas. This first part analyzes information systems from a management control perspective, emphasizing organization environment, technology, decision models and performance evaluation as determinants of information processing requirements; using cases and design projects to explore the management of information processing systems, major functional applications and impacts of information technology on individuals and society. The second part introduces the systems, procedures, and processes management employed to control operating activities, information reporting systems, and compliance with applicable laws, rules and regulations. Topics include design and evaluation perspectives of control environment, risk assessment, control activities, information and communication and monitoring.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: a) Understand the basic concepts of accounting information systems b) Be familiar with terminologies of information systems and techniques available to document an organization’s business processes c) Recognize the relationship between accounting information systems and internal controls d) Comprehend database management system (DBMS) and its structure e) Model an accounting information system in a database environment under Resource-Event-Agent (REA) framework f) Realize how to implement internal controls when an organization builds accounting information systems in the DBMS environment g) Be familiar with business processes and modeling issues in the revenue cycle and the expenditure cycle h) Understand how to strengthen internal controls in the revenue cycle and the expenditure cycle using information technologies i) Comprehend the security and confidentiality issues in e-commerce environment j) Know how to structure an AIS and make adjustments when combining multiple cycles using REA framework

title: Accounting Data Analytics and Business Intelligence
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy
description: While the production of data is expanding at an astonishing pace, companies are on average using only a fraction of the data out there. Recent survey by IMA (Institute of Management Accountants) in 2016 reveals significant skill gaps in many areas employers need most, especially identifying key data trends, data mining and extraction, operational analysis, technological acumen, statistical modeling and data analysis. This course targets towards accounting students who are interested in getting hands-on experience with data analytics and rising to the challenges and opportunities big data presents to the profession. The course will provide a basis for handling and analyzing large-scale data stored within and outside an organization and finding business insights from analyses. In the first two-thirds of the course, we will study the basic concepts and techniques related to data preprocessing, data exploration, model building and results interpretation. Instead of digging deep into technical details, the course will provide a broad survey of common approaches and focus on the pragmatic implementation of data analytics. In the latter one-third of the course, we will discuss the emerging trends in big data and their applications in the accounting profession as well as other industries. The course will try to utilize real datasets related to accounting and finance and enable students to “learn by doing” through hands-on experience with data.Prerequisites: Students who take the course need a basic background of statistics. Having a passion for learning new things is important for the course.
outcome: After taking the course, students should: (1) Have had hands-on experience with data analytics  a. R  b. RapidMiner (2) Master the basic concepts and techniques for data analytics  a. Perform basic data preprocessing  b. Summarize and visualize data  c. Find meaningful association among variables  d. Build models for classification and prediction (3) Have a better understanding of what tools and methods are most appropriate for different data analysis tasks at hand and their limitations  (4) Be able to competently interact on the topic of data analytics for business intelligence and work with other data experts (e.g. statisticians, programmers) in a project (5) Be able to approach business problems data analytically and deal with new trends in analytics techniques affecting businesses (6) Be able to envision future big data opportunities in accounting and other business functions

title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Business
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: This course equips students with a basic understanding of how the law, public policy and the political process affect business decision making in China and abroad. In addition to introduction to business law details, it intends to provide a conceptual framework that helps students manage more effectively in a business world heavily influenced by public sector and governmental forces.
outcome: Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to: a) Understand the commercial laws system of China and the principles behind b) Understand how commercial laws govern business entities c) Have a general understanding of Corporate Law, Bankruptcy Law, Security Law, Contract Law, and Bill Law of China which are related to business

title: Taxation in China
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy; or MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: This course is designed to familarize students with the Chinese tax law and practice. After an introduction to the normative and institutional backgrounds of tax administration, it will examine the country’s major state and local tax regimes. The course will also touch on administrative and professional aspects of tax practice in this emerging market economy.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: a) Understand some major tax issues and problems on a cross-border basis b) Analyze and solve international tax matters in light of relevant rules, regulations and practices

title: International Taxation Planning and Management
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy;Prerequisite: ACCT5160 Taxation and Tax Planning
description: This course introduces the tax concern of cross-border economic activities. It introduces the key concepts of international taxation, such as the tax jurisdiction of residence and source, international double taxation, relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements. It also examines measures to prevent international tax avoidance, procedural mechanisms by which international tax issues are resolved, and bilateral administrative issues.
outcome: After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: 1. identify and assess the tax effect of cross-border economic activities 2. understand the relief from double taxation under domestic law and double taxation agreements  3. identify and apply common types of anti-avoidance provisions designed to counter specified forms of international tax planning
recommended_readings: 1. Principles of International Taxation (latest edition), Angharad Miller and Lynne Oats, Bloomsbury Professional  2. International Tax Primer (latest edition), Brian J. Arnold, Kluwer Law International 3. Model Tax Convention on Income and on Capital (condensed version), Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development 4. International Taxation (latest edition), Joseph Isenbergh, Foundation Press 5. Klaus Vogel on Double Taxation Conventions (latest edition), Ekkehart Reimer, Alexander Rust, Kluwer Law International 6. Fundamentals of International Tax Planning, Raffaele Russo, International Bureau of Fiscal Documentation 7. International Taxation: Law and Practice in Hong Kong and China, Julien Chaisse and Michael Lang, CCH

title: Corporate Tax Planning and Risk Management
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: The course is designed for students to learn the evolution of the tax system from a historical perspective, and its relation with the political and economic systems. Topics include: 1) measuring daily tax compliance, 2) controlling for tax risk, 3) maximizing shareholder benefits and corporate after-tax profits, 4) minimizing tax burden through organizational structure, business model, and operating model, 5) using BEPS in cross-border investment and business processes, 6) maximizing corporate value and personal wealth by circumventing CRS constraints.
outcome: After completion of this course, students are expected to be able to: (1) understand the tax system and its relation with the political and economic systems (2) understand tax operations, tax compliance and tax risk control (3) understand how to maximize shareholder benefits and corporate value by minimizing tax burden of the organization
syllabus: Course syllabus: (1) Historical perspective - History of the US tax system - Evolution of the tax system in the Han, Song and Ming dynasties, and New China (2) Corporate tax compliance and risk control - Requirement of "five-in-one" model - Specific requirements for compliance - Establishment of risk control system - Construction of tax risk model (3) Tax planning measures - Construction of organizational structure - Choice of business model - Operation mode processing - Use of financial means - Cross-border tax planning
required_readings: To be provided by the course instructor.

title: Corporate Governance: A Global Perspective
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy; or Executive Master of Professional Accountancy; or MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: The OECD Guidelines for Corporate Governance identify four elements namely objectives, transparency, benchmarks and accountability as key factors that transcend both legal and national boundaries. As a concept it delineates the rights and responsibilities of each group of stakeholders in the company by providing for appropriate checks and balance to be incorporated into the process of performance, decision making and monitoring. This course will address issues within in the rubric of corporate governance from an accounting and legal perspective.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: a) Understand the important institutional and human factors in business operations b) Understand different governance issues and practices globally especially in the emerging markets such as China and Asia c) Know how to address and resolve some important corporate governance issues

title: Applied Corporate Governance for Capital Markets
description: This course equips the students with a deeper understanding of the current state of play as regards corporate governance principles and rules, and the institutions through which corporate governance rules are applied to capital market participants, with a special focus on the Hong Kong and mainland China capital markets, but also addresses the challenges and trends in the real-life market place and how the linkages between effective enterprise governance, risk management and compliance can contribute to superior business performance and thereby to enhanced investor confidence in the capital markets.Many diverse topics which impact how corporate governance is applied in practice in the capital markets, such as increasing regulatory supervision, GRC, key capital market participants, changes in the structure of the auditing profession, hot business transformation trends, a new enterprise business model, etc, are brought to life in an interlinking way using case studies and visiting business leaders to brief students and answer their questions.Students are encouraged throughout the course to think about practical solutions to enhance corporate governance practices in Hong Kong and mainland China’s capital markets.
outcome: This course emphasises the following expected learning outcomes to students: • Insight that corporate governance practices must be effectively implemented in real capital markets, not merely as a concept. • Able to understand the current corporate governance principles and rules.  • Learn about the key capital market participants in HK/China and their views on corporate governance in practice and future trends, in particular its application to Asian markets - regulators, exchanges, auditors, enterprise structures (Board, Supervisory Boards, Audit Committee, INEDs, etc), and other stakeholders globally and in HK/China. • Understand the new enterprise business model and GRC impact thereon. • Able to link GRC to the emerging business transformation trends, such as climate change and sustainability, cloud computing, sourcing and shared services, and IT privacy and security. • Able to formulate own ideas for effective implementation of corporate governance principles to tomorrow’s market place.
syllabus: • Concepts and practical knowledge of corporate governance to students and further develop their conceptual and analytical abilities in this area, through the use of case studies, interactive two-way discussions, and visiting business leaders to brief students and answer questions. • Benchmarking of the HK/China and global regulatory rules on corporate governance. • The new enterprise business model. • Hot business issues – increasing regulatory supervision, GRC, climate change and sustainability, cloud computing, sourcing and shared services, and IT privacy and security. • GRC includes knowledge-based risk management techniques and COSO controls. • Capital market participants’ roles and responsibilities. • Board, Audit Committee and INED roles, responsibilities and competencies. • The future of the accounting industry – what will the Big 4 look like in 5 years’ time? • Is Western-style corporate governance applicable to Asian markets? • Move to integrated reporting?
recommended_readings: • The OECD Principles of Corporate Governance, 2004. • HKEx Code on Corporate Governance Practices. • The UK Corporate Governance Code. • The International Corporate Governance Network, www.icgn.org. • Global Corporate Governance Forum, www.gcgf.org.

title: Corporate Governance: An East Asia Perspective
description: This course identifies the corporate governance challenges for companies in China and East Asia, and explores various mechanisms for strengthening their governance systems. We pay particular attention to the corporate governance issues of state-owned firms and entrepreneurial / family-controlled firms, which are prevalent in China and East Asia.The course adopts a multi-disciplinary approach, using theories from economics, law, political science and sociology, to provide a theoretical framework for understanding the different ownership structures and corporate governance systems around the world. Combining theories with practical knowledge of corporate governance practice, we tackle issues such as government intervention on state and non-state firms, accounting opacity and fraud, ineffective board monitoring, expropriation of controlling owners against minority shareholders, and succession in family firms.
outcome: By completion of the course, students would be able to: 1) understand how various country institutions such as the political economy, legal systems and social norms shape the corporate governance and accounting systems across countries 2) analyze how firms’ corporate governance and accounting systems, which are shaped by their own country institutions, operate across countries 3) identify the challenges and analyze the effectiveness of corporate governance and accounting systems of listed firms across countries, with a focus in Asia and China
syllabus: The course will start with a discussion on the recent corporate governance issues in the U.S. and the general theories from economics, finance and law underpinning the study of corporate governance. This is followed by a discussion of how country institutions such as political economy, legal system, and culture and social norms shape firms’ corporate governance around the world. We then focus on East Asia and China, exploring the unique institutional factors that shape their governance systems. We will identify the governance systems’ key advantages and challenges, understand the theoretical reasoning behind the systems and discuss solutions to these governance challenges.
required_readings: Detailed class notes, and four to five cases, all developed by the instructor.
recommended_readings: The instructor will occasionally recommend articles from business publications including Xin Pao, The New Fortune, Cai Jin, Cai Xin, The 21st Century Economic Report, The Asian Wall Street Journal, The South China Morning Post, The Economist, Business Week, and so forth.

title: Accounting and Management Planning for Enterprises
requirements: For students in Master in Accountancy
description: “What distinguishes the successful entrepreneur and promoter from other people is precisely the fact that he does not let himself be guided by what was and is, but arranges his affairs on the ground of his opinion about the future. He sees the past and present as other people do; but he judges the future in a different way." (Human Action, Ludwig von Mises, 1966)Entrepreneurial activities have become a potent source of economic power that generates enormous job opportunities and business innovation globally. This is particularly spectacular in the context of China where there are numerous cases of successful and failure cases of privately owned enterprises and collectively owned township and village enterprises growing from an embryonic stage into a larger firm. The course adopts a “life-cycle” approach and develops a set of accounting and managerial skills to analyze companies from the start-up stage to eventually cashing out.

title: Financial Instruments and Hedge Accounting
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy
description: 1. Introduce accounting recognition, derecognition, and impairment of financial instruments which include financial assets, liabilities, equity and derivatives2. Introduce hedge accounting3. Introduce framework of using derivatives to manage market risks such as foreign exchange risk, interest rate risk, inflation risk, equity risk and commodity risk4. Study and discuss real-life hedging cases
outcome: • Students will learn financial instruments commonly used in firms, especially in banks and other financial institutions. • Students will learn accounting treatments, including recognition, derecognition and impairment of financial instruments.• Students will understand derivatives and its link with risk management. • Students will learn how to use derivatives to hedge various market risks such as foreign exchange, interest rate, inflation, equity and commodity risks.   • Students will learn accounting treatments of hedging activities.
syllabus: Class 1 （第一課） Classification of financial asset （金融資產的分類）Class 2 （第二課） Classification of financial liability and equity （金融負債和權益的分類）Class 3 （第三課） Derivatives and embedded derivatives （衍生工具和嵌入的衍生工具）Class 4 （第四課） Recognition and derecognition of financial asset and liability （確認和終止確認金融資產和負債）Class 5 （第五課） Impairment of financial assets （金融資產的減值損失）Class 6 （第六課） Mid-term examination （期中考試）Class 7 （第七課） Hedge accounting framework: Cash flow hedge, fair value hedge, and foreign operation hedge （套期會計的框架：現金流套期、公允價值套期和境外經營套期）Class 8 （第八課） Hedging foreign exchange risk and foreign operation （對匯率風險和境外經營的套期）Class 9 （第九課） Hedging interest rate risk （對利率的套期）Class 10 （第十課） Hedging equity risk and stock-based compensation plans （對股權風險和股權激勵計劃的套期）Class 11 （第十一課） Hedging commodity risk （對商品風險的套期）Class 12 （第十二課） Hedging inflation risk （對通貨膨脹風險的套期）Class 13 （第十三課） Final examination （期末考試）
required_readings: Accounting standards published by The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB)
recommended_readings: Publications from IASB, FASB, PWC, KPMG, Deloitte, and Ernst & Young

title: Accounting and Corporate Strategies
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: Making and correctly implementing business strategies are one of the most important tasks for firms’ high level management. This course aims to help students to (1) understand the relationship between their firm’s existence, development and the increasing of their firm’s value; (2) study the role of the strategic management in the development process of their firms; (3) improve students’ ability of making corporate strategies by using analytical tools; (4) improve students’ leadership capacity and the ability of implementing corporate strategy, including the communication skills between firms’ financial management and stakeholders.
outcome: Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to: a) Understand the relationship between development and value creation of a company and the role of strategic management for a company’s development b) Make use of various kinds of tools to analyze and propose strategy c) Enhance their capability to communicate as a financial manager with colleagues of other divisions with regard to corporate strategy

title: Managerial Economics and Business Strategy for Accounting Managers
requirements: For students in Executive Master of Professional Accountancy
description: Rational and foresight business strategies will help firms to succeed in a competitive market, and to strengthen their capability to develop continuously. This course is based on the basic theory and framework of Managerial Economics, particularly designed for CFO, through easy and readable language and business cases, introducing and demonstrating the heart of Managerial Economics to help CFOs to make successful business strategies.
outcome: Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to: a) Sort out the crucial elements for decision-making from a complex context of business b) Understand the basic principles of game theory and how these principles could be applied c) Think from the opponents perspectives in order to make the best strategy which may ultimately be conducive to a win-win situation for all stakeholders

title: Independent Study in Accounting
requirements: For students in Master of Accountancy
description: Independent study gives students added flexibility to design study programmes suited to a particular area of interest or to delve more deeply into a specific topic. Students need to find a faculty member willing to serve as the supervisor, and together, devise a format. There are a wide range of possibilities under independent study. The more common alternatives are: (a) Selection of a topic not normally covered in our curriculum in which the student has an interest. Normally the student would prepare a literature review on the selected topic. It would then be common for the student to perform some application or extension of this body of knowledge by extending or substantiating that knowledge by some data collection. (b) Preparation of a case and accompanying teacher’s note. The case must be based on real organizations and substantial data collection would be expected. The student would be expected to demonstrate application of theory in preparation of the teacher’s note.

title: Issues in Financial Accounting
description: Current research topics in financial accounting. These include accounting information and capital market behaviour, the economic consequences of both mandatory and voluntarily public announcements made by firms, effects of agency costs and debt convenants on the behaviour of firms’ reporting choices, fundamental analysis of accounting data, compensation schemes and financial reporting.

syllabus: Empirical financial accounting topics focusing on capital markets and the use of accounting information in various contracting settings:1. title: Independent Study
description: The purpose of this course is to expose graduate students to special topics not otherwise covered. Prior to taking this course, students should submit a proposal to and get approval from the instructor-in-charge stating the purposes and major objectives of their study. Details regarding how the study will be conducted are decided through consultation with their instructor-in-charge. The instructor may also ask the students to write reports throughout the semester, for example, a mid-course progress report and an end-of-course final report. This course requires research which is not a significant duplication of the thesis.

title: Issues in Managerial Accounting
description: Current research topics in managerial accounting. These include analysis of information values, theory of syndicates and teams; organization form and hierarchy, advanced topics in cost allocations and transfer pricing, decision models in management accounting, management accounting for multi-national corporations, agency issues in executive contracts, contingency theory and design of management accounting systems, behavioural dimensions of management accounting.

title: Research Methodology in Accounting
description: The course is designed to equip students with skills necessary for advanced research in accounting areas. Topics covered will include identification of research problems, development of research hypotheses, research design, data collection and processing, statistical tests, interpretation of results, and writing of research reports. Selected papers and topical research issues will also be discussed. The emphasis will be on the application of the research methods to solving accounting-related problems.

title: Current Topics in Accounting Research
description: The course explores current topics in a specific area of accounting research. Through a combination of lectures and seminars, students discuss recent literature and academic works to enhance their knowledge and skill to conduct research in accounting utilizing tools and paradigms at the frontier of such technologies.
outcome: By completion of the course, students will be able to: L1: Master basic theoretical concepts in accounting research  L2: Develop a good understanding of the evolution of accounting research L3: Assess the validity of research work L4: Critique accounting research by applying basic accounting theories L5: Develop basic understanding of the common methodologies used in accounting research
syllabus: 1. Research methodologies illustrated by classic papers in the theories of property rights and transaction costs2.
